caption: I recommend visiting this location to anyone that likes to walk through historic locations.  It is an interesting piece of Paris history. As an amateur history buff, I enjoy visiting ancient historic remains even if it's simply the remains of a wall from 800 years ago.
A small ruin of the original wall around paris. For history buffs but definitely not worth going out of your way.

History abounds and you can walk past incredible things like this in Paris all day long and not even know they are there. As the sign says, translated to English: "History of Paris Precinct of Philippe Auguste. In 1190, before his departure for the third crusade, Philippe Auguste (1165-1223) asked the inhabitants to contribute to the security of the city by the construction of a wall of about 5 km, completed around 1210. This curtain, high of ten meters and crowned with a crenellated walkway, is pierced by about ten doors. Bounded to the west by the fortress of the Louvre, built to protect it in the early years of the 13th century, to the east by the Place de Grève, to the north by Les Halles, and to the south by the town of Sainte-Geneviève, it defines a capital of 250 hectares: henceforth, the palace, the treasury and the archives are permanently fixed there, even if the king does not always reside there. This is the first attempt to unite the three Parisian districts: the "Cité", the religious, administrative and judicial heart, the "Ville", the economic center located around the ports of the right bank, and the nascent "University" on the left bank.
Love history! This is was remains of the ols city wall.
Not that much to look at. The section is a minor tourist attraction, might be worth a look if you are going to Pantheon or are in the neighbourhood. The wall was constructed in 1190-1210.

The Wall of Philip Augustus is the oldest city wall of Paris whose plan is accurately known. Partially integrated into buildings, more traces of it remain than of the later fortifications which were destroyed and replaced by the Grands Boulevards.

Off-beat must-visit site for history buffs. Look out for other remains of the wall in the Marais and Châtelet area. Also sites on the left-bank including one in an underground car park in the Rue Mazarine.
For history lovers, this is your place.
A glimpse of ancient Paris.

On the excursion we looked at part of the ancient city wall of Philip Augustus and the Montgomery Tower. It was built around 1200. A thick wall that protected from enemies. Now this part of the wall is integrated into modern buildings and serves as a wall for a children's school playground.

Even if it would benefit from being better highlighted in view of its obvious historical past, this section of the enclosure reveals a real medieval trace of a bygone but nevertheless founding Paris. I recommend passing by when visiting the Arènes de Lutèce to look back 800 years. Don’t forget to take a look at the little sign “History of Paris”
We were walking around and we noticed this section of the old wall, there is a small notice on a plaque next to it.
There is a mistake on the plate. The correct date of inauguration of the enclosure on the right bank is XIII century.
A very last vestige of the history of Paris, it is a section of wall remaining from an old Parisian fortification, this is located just behind the pantheon on rue Clovis
A small piece of the surrounding wall built under Philippe Auguste if you want to see a wall in fairly good condition go to Provins at least you can climb it.
There are places in Paris where the remains of the wall of Philippe-Auguste are more impressive.  The interest of rue Clics is to show the thickness of the wall, which is impressive.
What a beautiful wall! monuments
Among the places that show us how historic Paris is.
We may prefer the restaurant next door to the historical-architectural curiosity which will only satisfy passers-by with a strong imagination.
I had a pleasant time in the company of these warm stones
Very beautiful
The history of Paris begins there,,,
I live at the foot of the wall
He thinks
Absolutely worth discovering
